projects.title: How Much Does It Cost to Grow Old in Your Home? Use Our Remodeling Tool
projects.description:
Most people underestimate what it takes to make their home age-ready – until they need to.

This tool turned complex construction cost into a simple, visual cost guide.

Users explored each part of a typical home — kitchen, bath, living room — seeing in real time how ramps, touchless faucets, or grab bars changed both comfort and cost.

As upgrades appeared, isometric blueprints softened into lived-in color to combine precision and warmth.

projects.title: Tipping Is Everywhere and Consumers Are Fed Up. Here’s How Some Are Coping.
projects.description:
Tipping is now embedded into American daily life. But what’s socially expected, and how people actually tip, can be wildly inconsistent. We wanted readers to explore that tension through their own choices.

Readers encountered everyday scenarios, from coffee counters to dinners with terrible service, and decided how much they’d tip. The game then showed how other WSJ readers responded, forming a living snapshot of social norms in flux.

The design leaned into skeuomorphic familiarity — a simulated tablet screen — making the experience playful and sharable.

projects.title: Why Your Top Tax Rate Isn’t What You Actually Pay
projects.description:
Taxes are full of traps for the uninitiated. Most people hear “top marginal rate” and imagine that every dollar they earn is taxed at that rate. In reality, the system is far more nuanced. We wanted readers to see the truth at a glance.

The interactive calculator let users input their income and immediately see their effective tax rate. Animated charts broke down each marginal bracket, showing how only slices of income were taxed at higher percentages.

Financial professionals confirmed the design worked: readers grasped complex concept in seconds. By turning abstract tables into a visual story, the piece bridged the gap between data and intuition.

projects.title: The New Normal: Spending $400 at the Hair Salon
projects.description:
Inflation has changed what “normal” spending means, even when it comes to haircuts.

The project used a higher-or-lower mechanic: each guess brought readers closer to the true cost, creating a simple game loop that kept them engaged while surfacing broader insights about inflation and lifestyle spending.

Bold photography and quick, responsive interactions kept the focus on intuition. Each guess became its own small data point, showing how perceptions of prices diverge and how quickly those baselines can shift.

projects.title: Who Owns SpongeBob? AI Shakes Hollywood’s Creative Foundation
projects.description:
As AI tools begin to churn out screenplays, we built a generator to test how creative they could really be.

Readers assembled their own chaotic T.V. scripts — starring aliens, barristas and talking hamsters at Taylor Swift concerts or at Davos — while learning how models are trained and who legally owns the results.

It was both satire and explainer: a toybox interface that opened a real discussion about authorship, originality, and ownership in an automated era.

projects.title: Abortion Is on the Ballot in Five States in Midterm Elections
projects.description:
In the 2022 midterms, five states held abortion-related ballot initiatives, each with distinct legal language.

We built a live dashboard to track them as votes came in. Each state could be explored independently, but the layout encouraged readers to take a broader view of national sentiment.

It was designed to be a calm visual system, built to handle the speed and volatility of election night.
